content: English statement is sub-par in every aspect. Even overlooking wording/language mistakes, the statement is difficult and unpleasant to process and/or plain wrong, it's hard to pinpoint due to the odd wording. Desperately needs to be revised.
This contribution hasn’t received enough positive votes from the community. The "FASTEST" option has therefore been deactivated.

Hey :)

I just had this in Clash of Code.

From the 1st to the 8th, we all agreed, that this was really badly explained.

Please, work again on the description.
We all lost our hair.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: A little challenging but fun

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Starting to code the solution without really understand the problem, ends up to a nested cycle solution (for(1..n) of a for(i..n)).
Correctly recognizing the problem makes it being resolved fast with 1 line of code.

I like this kind of challenge because if you start to code the solution in no-brain mode (without thinking about the problem), you'll end up to a nested cycle solution (for(1..n) of a for(i..n)).
But when you recognize that this is the same problem Gauss resolved when he was 8, then you can write a 1-line-of-code solution. 
Well done, I love it!

Here's an alternate statement that I think makes the problem more clear. Take what you will from it

Harsh must choose a subgroup of people from a single file line of N people. A subgroup may be of any size from 1 to N, but the subgroup must be taken from a continuous set of the original line.

For example, given a line of 3 people [A,B,C] Harsh can create any one of the following subgroups: A, AB, ABC, B, BC, C, for a total of 6 different combinations. Please note however, he cannot create group AC, because A and C are not next to each other in the original line.

Given T lines of N people, for each line output the total number of unique subgroups Harsh can make.

Hmmm, this is a tricky one. I hate to admit I spent more than 15 minutes trying to come up with a statistical solution before finally finding the much simpler actual solution (I didn't realize that you couldn't skip...i.e. you couldn't have a group of 1,3 without 2). Maybe if you explain that a little better. Make it clear that "all members of each group must be next to each other in the line." Or even just putting the combos in a different order, for example:

([1], [1,2], [1,2,3], [2], [2,3], [3])

or even

([1], [1,2], [1,2,3], 
[2], [2,3], 
[3])

I liked this challenge, but I think it should be better explained.

My solution:
for i in range(int(input())):
    n=int(input())
    print(n*(n+1)//2)

I found it hard to understand, what the question is. You are writing 'now Harsh want to choose some contiguous subset of participants from the group' - but what group is meant? Do you want to say: Now Harsh want to choose one of the possible groups?

If I guess the problem right, for me the following would be clearer:
given 3 participants (imagine them standing in list [1, 2, 3])
[3] can be in only one group, there is no one behind him
[2] can be in two groups [2], [2,3] 
[1] can be in three groups [1], [1,2],[1,2,3]
- [1,3] is no possible group for [1] because [3] is not behind [1].

The question is: How many groups are possible?

I don't think this problem suits reverse mode well enough.

As for fastest and shortest, I like it.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Excepte from my previous comment the contribution is good

I have only one thing that bothers me: you say " in a group with a person behind him". In your example, you say that there are 3 participant. So 1 is in first line. He should be able to form a group with 2 and 3. In the contrary, 3 is in last position. So he should be able to be only in his own group. 

I would write: 
1 can form group ([1, 2, 3])
2 can form group ([2, 3]).
3 can form only solo ([3]) team as there is no one behind him.
Why is the solo group [1] counted three times in the example you show ?

it is a total number of options. So there can be multiple possible option to pick a group then from each group there are a number of possible arrangements.
does this help Or should I change some statement if it is not clear?
thanks for the suggestion. Made the changes

I guess my wordings were unclear, but I have made some changes to the statement but kept the original structure to avoid making it too easy. else it will be a problem only to use "sum of special series".
and example and the first few test cases are fairly simple to get the insight of the problem.
I have made some changes to the problem statement. but "contiguous" refers to the continuous elements.
and our calm
Yeah, that's true. It could just be my failure in trying to make the problem more complicated than it is

I can understand that you don't want to make the problem too simple. But the difficulty should not be in figuring out what is the question. The difficulty should be: what is the answer to the question.

okay, changed the modes.
thanks for the suggestion.

This was not told in the statement. You said "Harsh want to choose some contiguous subset of participants from the group. You have to tell what is the total number of possible options". So the [1] is one (and only one) group.

Besides, in the example, you say : "for group 3 he can choose ([1], [2], [3], [1, 2], [2, 3], [1, 2, 3])". Why ? For instance, 3 does not belong to the group [1], does he ?  

There is definitely something missing in your statement, but I don't see how to change it to fit the answer.

I guess a total number of possible "options" is what is confusing?
should I change it to the "total number of possible ways"?
This is synonym ; you have to clarify why the group say [1] from person n° 1 is different from the same group [1] but made from the person n°2

okay, I got what you meant!
well, I have updated the statement and test cases accordingly.
Ok that's good :)
